result.author: By Reuters
result.title: Full Government of Mali Resigns; Premier Is Named
result.opening: A town planning minister, Moussa Mara, will become prime minister, a presidential spokesman said on state television late on Saturday.

result.author: By Taylor Barnes
result.title: Brazil Sends In Armed Forces to Assist in Policing Poor Area
result.opening: The operation is a part of a five-year-old “pacification” policing program, which has established permanent police patrols in select slums in Rio de Janeiro ahead of this year’s World Cup tournament.

result.author: By Alison Smale
result.title: Tending Their Wounds, Vowing to Fight On
result.opening: Some veterans of Kiev’s Independence Square are healing abroad, physically and mentally, from the bloody protests that helped topple Ukraine’s president.

result.author: By Palko Karasz And Alison Smale
result.title: Election in Hungary Tests Nation’s Tilt to the Right
result.opening: Prime Minister Viktor Orban and his coalition appear headed for victory when Hungarians vote on Sunday, but the election will gauge the depth of voters’ support and their interest in pushing the nation further right.

result.author: By Dan Bilefsky
result.title: Citizenship-for-Cash Program in Malta Stirs Security Concerns in European Union
result.opening: Opponents said the program, under which foreigners can pay to buy Maltese citizenship, could open the door to the West for criminals or terrorists.

result.author: By Anne Barnard
result.title: Break in Syrian War Brings Brittle Calm
result.opening: The Syrian government claims it is winning the war and it can afford to be magnanimous; it is offering reconciliation to repentant opponents, and some are accepting.

result.title: A Change in Atmosphere in Central Syria
result.opening: The boom of shelling no longer dominates the days and nights.

result.author: By Mark Mazzetti
result.title: Delays in Effort to Refocus C.I.A. From Drone War
result.opening: Despite avowals about the need to refocus the agency on its original missions of analysis, intelligence collecting and espionage, the paramilitary operations prove hard to give up.
